query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary:
- Treating bats for white-nose syndrome with a probiotic bacterium was evaluated in two randomized, controlled studies: one in Canada and one in the USA (2008). In Canada, treatment at the time of infection increased survival for little brown bats within laboratory cages and reduced disease symptoms; treatment 21 days prior to infection did not increase survival and was associated with worse symptoms (2008). In the USA, treatment within a mine increased survival for free-flying little brown bats, but survival of caged bats and disease severity did not differ from untreated bats (2008).
- Breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome has no studies evaluating its effects (2009).
- Decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves to reduce spread of the pathogen has no studies evaluating effects on bat populations (2006).

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "white-nose syndrome bats effectiveness strategies treatment management evidence", "k": 3, "offset": 0}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to reduce white-nose syndrome infection. One study was in Canada and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?
relevant_summary: Relevant structures include: green bridges, which in one UK study were used by 97% of bats crossing a road (action_id: 979); overpasses, which were used by some bat species in studies from Ireland and France, with one UK study reporting two-thirds of bats used a vegetated overpass while an unvegetated paved overpass was not used (action_id: 977); and hop-overs, which are proposed but for which no studies have yet evaluated their effects on bat populations (action_id: 980).

query: How do different methods for restricting public access to bat hibernation sites, such as gates versus fences, compare in their effects on bat populations?
relevant_summary: Across 11 studies on cave gates, population responses were mixed: three of four before-and-after studies reported more or similar numbers of bats after gates were installed, while one found fewer bats; two before-and-after studies found more bats after increasing gate entrance size; a replicated before-and-after study found population increases or reduced declines for 13 of 20 Indiana bat colonies after gating; a replicated site comparison in Spain found no difference in population growth between caves with and without gates (999). One site comparison found bats in a gated cave lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave (999). Behaviourally, one study reported more circling and fewer entries at gated cave entrances; another found funnel-design gates were passed through more than round bar or angle iron designs; a randomized study found fewer bats passed through when bar spacing was reduced; and one before-and-after study reported fewer bats emerged from a gated cave than from a cave with a fence (999). For fencing, a replicated site comparison in Spain found no difference in population growth or occupancy between caves with and without fencing or gates (1991). A controlled before-and-after study in the USA found significantly more southeastern myotis and gray myotis emerged after a steel gate was replaced with a fence (1991).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of installing cave gates on bat populations. Six studies were in the USA and five studies were in Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Three of four before-and-after studies (including one replicated study and one controlled study) in the Netherlands, the USA, Spain and Turkey found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access. The other study found fewer bats in caves after gates were installed. Two before-and-after studies in the USA and Spain found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased. One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat. One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Condition (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave.

BEHAVIOUR (5 STUDIES)   

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the occupancy rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Behaviour change (4 studies): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study in the USA found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed. One replicated study in the USA found that bats flew through gates with a funnel design more frequently than gates with a round bar or angle iron design. One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fewer bats flew through cave gates when the spacing between horizontal bars was reduced. One before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence."

query: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?
relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, increasing turbine cut-in speeds reduced bat fatalities in most cases: ten of 12 studies in the USA and Canada reported fewer bat fatalities when cut-in speed was increased, including cases where feathering was also applied; two studies did not find reductions but had small samples or short treatment periods [1960]. Preventing blades from turning at low wind speeds (feathering) reduced bat fatalities in five of six studies in the USA and Canada; one study with automatic feathering found no reduction [970]. Slowing blade rotation at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities in one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada [2939].

query: Instead of culling, what alternative non-lethal actions can be used to manage human-bat conflicts?
relevant_summary: Two replicated, controlled studies in Madagascar and Mauritius reported that non-lethal measures to prevent bats from accessing fruit reduced damage in orchards; tested measures included an organic deterrent spray, hanging plastic flags in trees, covering individual tree branches with nylon net bags, and ringing bells in lychee trees which deterred most Madagascan flying foxes [1953]. For conflicts related to rabies transmission, actions proposing to replace culling with non-lethal methods of preventing vampire bats from spreading rabies to humans or livestock have no studies evaluating their effects [1979; 1950]. Providing training to wildlife control operators on the least harmful ways of removing bats from roosts has no studies evaluating effects [2945]. Excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation has no studies evaluating effects [1961].

query: How effective are different public education and engagement strategies for improving bat conservation outcomes?
relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluate the effects of educating the public to improve perceptions of bats on behaviour towards bats, so effectiveness is unknown [1000]. One study in the UK reported that during a five-year landowner engagement project the overall population of greater horseshoe bats at four maternity roosts increased [1936]. The same project recorded 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha of land [1936].

query: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, what alternative lighting strategies can be used to minimize disturbance to bats?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents reports that using red lighting rather than white or green can affect bat responses: one Netherlands study found higher activity for one of three bat species groups under red vs. white or green light, another found similar activity of commuting Daubenton’s bats in culverts under red vs. white or green light, and a UK study found more soprano pipistrelles emerged when lit with red vs. white light, with no difference between red and blue lights (2021). Ultraviolet filtering on lights increased soprano pipistrelle activity at hedges compared to unfiltered lights, with no increase for common pipistrelle (1020). Measures that can change insect attraction include using low-intensity, narrow yellow/low-UV lighting, which attracted fewer moths than higher-intensity, broader-spectrum UV‑including lights in Germany (3902), and using shielded “full cut‑off” lights fitted with blinds and shorter‑wavelength filters, which attracted fewer individual moths and species than conventional lights in Slovenia (3904). Additional strategies suggested but with no direct bat-population studies found include directing lighting away from bat access points or habitats (2019), using glazing treatments to reduce light spill from inside buildings (2022), and choosing ‘warm white’ rather than ‘cool’ LEDs (2020).

query: To protect bats from the impacts of mining operations, what actions can be taken during and after mine closure and reclamation?
relevant_summary: Identified actions related to mining closure and reclamation include: retaining access points for bats following mine closures [1962]; excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation [1961]; and retaining bat access points to caves [1990]. For each of these actions, no studies were found that evaluated their effects on bat populations [1962, 1961, 1990].

query: What are the most effective legislative actions for protecting bats and their habitats?
relevant_summary: Legally protecting bat habitats has been studied in five studies (four in Europe, one in India) with mixed but generally positive effects: protected sites had higher overall bat activity in France and India, higher activity for Daubenton’s bats over rivers on farms in UK protected areas, higher activity for common noctule bats in protected forests in Europe though overall activity did not differ, and bat species counts were greater at protected sites in one France study, while two studies (Europe and India) found no difference in species richness between protected and unprotected forests; distributions of 10 of 11 species in Spain overlapped with designated protected areas more than by chance (2045). No studies were found evaluating the effects of introducing and enforcing legislation to control hunting of bats on bat populations (984). No studies were found evaluating the effects of enforcing existing legislation for habitat protection on mammal populations (2916).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects of legally protecting bat habitats on bat populations. Four studies were in Europe and one was in India.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in India found that the composition of bat species was similar in protected forest and unprotected forest fragments.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or paired sites studies in Europe and India found that the number of bat species did not differ between protected and unprotected forests or forest fragments. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that protected sites had a greater number of bat species than unprotected sites.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that the activity (relative abundance) of Daubenton’s bats was higher over rivers on farms in protected areas than in unprotected areas. One replicated, paired sites study in Europe found that the activity of common noctule bats was higher in protected forests than unprotected forests, but bat activity overall did not differ. Two replicated, site comparison studies in France and India found higher overall bat activity, higher activity of three of six bat species/species groups and a greater number of bats in protected sites and forests than unprotected sites and forests.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Use (1 study): One study in Spain found that the distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with areas designated to protect them significantly more than by chance."
}

query: For bat conservation related to transportation infrastructure, what are the documented benefits and limitations of providing or retaining roosts in bridges and culverts?
relevant_summary: Documented benefits: Maintaining existing bridge roosts allowed a Daubenton’s bat maternity colony to continue using a bridge in similar numbers after repairs retained crevices [1966]. When roosts were maintained during bridge replacements, Yuma myotis and Mexican free-tailed bats recolonized most roosts in similar numbers to before works [1966]. Creating replacement roost spaces in bridges led to recolonization by bats in similar or greater numbers at four of eight sites [1967]. Documented limitations: Alternative roosts (bat houses) provided during bridge replacements were used by fewer Mexican free-tailed bats than the original at one site and were not used at three sites [2942]. When roosts were maintained, pallid bats did not return after bridge works despite other species recolonizing [1966]. Creating replacement roost spaces had mixed outcomes, with only half of monitored sites achieving similar or greater recolonization [1967].

query: How does the evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats compare to that for planting new ones?
relevant_summary: For managing existing hedgerows for bats, two UK studies provide evidence: a replicated, site comparison study found more bat species along hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior than along hedges trimmed the previous winter, and higher activity for two of eight bat species/species groups on these less frequently trimmed hedges; a replicated, paired-sites study found pipistrelle activity did not differ between hedges managed for wildlife on agri-environment scheme farms and hedges on conventional farms (1943). In contrast, for planting new hedges, no studies were found that evaluated effects on bat populations (1942).

query: How does the evidence for legally protecting bat habitats compare to legally protecting bats during development activities?
relevant_summary: Evidence for legally protecting bat habitats includes five studies (four in Europe, one in India) reporting mixed community-level results (similar or greater species richness/composition in protected vs. unprotected sites) and multiple cases of higher bat activity or abundance in protected areas, as well as species distributions overlapping with designated protection areas more than by chance [2045]. In contrast, evidence for legally protecting bats during development comes from four UK studies, focusing on behavioural and roost-site outcomes: increased numbers of development licences issued and low rates of post-development monitoring; negative impacts on bat roosts with 68% destroyed; limited use of compensation roosts (5/28 used; 31–67% use rates reported) and no studies reporting community or population responses [1935].

query: In the agricultural sector, what are the observed effects of organic farming systems compared to conventional farming on bat populations?
relevant_summary: Across 12 studies comparing organic and conventional farms, community composition did not differ in one replicated, paired study in the USA [961]. In seven studies assessing richness/diversity, five found no difference in the number of bat species between organic and non-organic farms, while two reported more species on organic farms [961]. For population responses, nine studies on activity showed mixed results: five found no difference in overall bat activity (including common pipistrelle) between organic and conventional farms, while four reported higher overall bat activity, higher feeding activity, higher Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and higher activity for four of seven species on organic farms [961]. Two UK studies reported higher Myotis spp. activity over water and rivers on organic farms, with no differences for other species or habitats [961]. One study in France found higher activity for two of three species over organic fields than over two of three types of conventionally managed fields [961]. Related evidence from reduced-chemical systems shows that farms or grasslands with few or no chemical inputs had different bat species compositions than high-input farms, higher diversity of insect-eating bats in coffee systems with few/no chemicals, more bat species over grassland with moderate/no fertiliser than with high fertiliser, higher overall bat activity with few/no chemical inputs, and better body condition in fruit-eating bats in no-chemical silvopastoral systems compared to conventional chemical-use areas [2013].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "organic farming bats agricultural sector effects of organic farming on bat populations", "k": 3, "offset": 0}

Twelve studies evaluated the effects of using organic farming instead of conventional farming on bat populations. Eight studies were in Europe, two in the USA, one in Canada and one in Chile.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, paired sites study in the USA found that the composition of bat species did not differ between organic and non-organic farms.
Richness/diversity (7 studies): Five of seven replicated, paired sites or site comparison studies in Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile found that the number of bat species did not differ between organic and non-organic farms. The other two studies found more bat species on organic farms than non-organic farms.

POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Abundance (12 studies): Five of nine replicated, paired sites or site comparison studies in Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile found that overall bat activity (relative abundance) and common pipistrelle activity did not differ between organic and non-organic farms. The other four studies found higher overall bat activity, bat feeding activity, Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and activity of four of seven bat species on organic farms than non-organic farms. Two replicated, paired sites and site comparison studies in the UK found higher activity of Myotis species over water and rivers on organic farms than non-organic farms, but no differences were found for other species or habitats. COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Portugal found that farms using few or no chemicals had different compositions of bat species to farms using high chemical inputs.
Richness/diversity (2 studies): One site comparison study in Mexico found that coffee agroforestry plantations using few or no chemicals had a higher diversity of insect-eating bat species than plantations with high chemical inputs, but the diversity of fruit and nectar-eating bat species did not differ. One paired sites study in Germany recorded more bat species over grassland with moderate or no fertiliser applications than grassland with high fertiliser applications.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): Two site comparison or paired sites studies (one replicated) in Portugal and Germany found that farms or grasslands with few or no chemical inputs had higher overall bat activity (relative abundance) than those using high chemical inputs.
Condition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Columbia found that great fruit-eating bats captured in ‘silvopastoral’ areas that used no chemicals, along with agroforestry, had higher body weights and body condition scores than those in conventional farming areas that used chemicals.

}

query: During building developments, what alternatives to bat exclusion have been studied to mitigate disturbance to roosts?
relevant_summary: Studies have examined: (1) creating alternative roosts within developments, including bat boxes, lofts/barns, bat houses, bat walls and purpose-built roosts; reported use varied—bat boxes/lofts/barns were used at 13–74% of development sites, lofts/barns were used by maternity colonies at one of 19 sites, two studies found no use of bat houses or a bat wall after exclusion, and before-and-after studies reported purpose-built roosts being used in higher or similar numbers at some sites but lower at others; a UK review found new boxes/lofts replacing destroyed roosts were four times less likely to be used than retained roosts (949). (2) relocating access points to roosts; one Irish study found fewer brown long-eared bats used a roost and no bats flew through relocated access points, while a UK study found few bats used a ‘bend’ access but numbers increased after installing a ‘straight’ access (946). (3) retaining existing roosts and access points; an Irish study found similar numbers roosting after retaining access points during renovations, a UK study found four of nine retained roosts used as maternity colonies with similar or greater numbers in two cases after development, and a UK review reported bats used two-thirds of retained/modified roosts after development and retained roosts were more likely to be used than newly created roosts (947).

query: What factors are associated with the successful use of artificial bat roosts by bats?
relevant_summary: Modifying the microclimate to reduce internal roost temperatures in artificial roosts within buildings was associated with increased bat abundance after modification [2052]. Heated bat boxes showed limited use: they were used by common pipistrelles at one of seven sites and not by maternity colonies, and none of 12 heated boxes in churches were used by displaced Natterer’s bats [2052]. Artificial hollows cut into trees with two different entrance designs were used by roosting long-eared bats in 8 of 16 cases [2047]. Artificial caves or hibernacula were used by bats, with up to four species recorded using them, and one artificial hibernaculum showed increasing use in each of nine years after construction [2049].

query: What are the documented benefits and harms of installing gates at cave and mine entrances for bat conservation?
relevant_summary: Documented benefits: Before-and-after studies reported more or similar numbers of bats after installing cave gates in some sites, including increased numbers after enlarging gated entrances at two caves, and population increases or reduced rates of decline for 13 of 20 Indiana bat colonies; some studies found no difference in population growth rates or occupancy between gated and ungated caves; at mines, bat activity (relative abundance) remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines, and 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, though responses varied with gate design and time since installation [999, 1963]. Documented harms: Some studies found fewer bats or fewer species after gates were installed at caves and mines; bats at entrances circled more and entered less after gates were installed; up to 7% of bats collided with mine gates; four mines were abandoned when ‘ladder’ design gates were used; bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate lost more body mass than in a nearby unmodified cave; bats flew through funnel-design gates more frequently than round bar or angle iron gates, and fewer bats flew through when spacing between horizontal bars was reduced; significantly fewer bats emerged from a gated cave compared with a fenced cave [1963, 999].

BEHAVIOUR (6 STUDIES)      

Use (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the USA found that 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, however bats abandoned four mines with ‘ladder’ design gates. One replicated study in the USA found that gate design and time since gate installation had varied effects on the presence of four bat species.
Behaviour change (4 studies): Four replicated, before-and-after or site comparison studies in the USA and Australia found that bats at mine entrances circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed.

OTHER (2 STUDIES)

query: As an alternative to increasing turbine cut-in speeds, what other operational changes can reduce bat mortality at wind farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several operational alternatives: Preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than conventionally operated turbines in five of six studies, though one study found no reduction [970]. Slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities in one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada [2939]. Automatically reducing blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high resulted in fewer bat fatalities in two replicated studies (Germany and USA), for all bat species combined and for five species [971]. Fitting turbines with ultrasonic deterrents had mixed effects on fatalities across studies, with reported changes ranging from 21–51% fewer fatalities in one year to 2% more to 64% fewer in another, and species-specific or signal-type–specific responses [968]. No studies were found evaluating the effects of removing turbine lighting to reduce bat and insect attraction [969] or painting turbines to reduce insect attraction [1959].

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds on bat populations. Five studies were in the USA and one was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Survival (6 studies): Five of six studies (including five replicated, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’), or feathering along with increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other study found that automatically feathering turbine blades at low wind speeds did not reduce bat fatalities.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of deterring bats from wind turbines using ultrasound on bat populations. The four studies were in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Survival (3 studies): Three replicated, randomized, controlled studies (one with a before-and-after trial in the second year) in the USA found mixed results. In the first year of one study, 21-51% fewer bats were killed at turbines with an ultrasonic deterrent fitted than at control turbines, but in the second year, from 2% more to 64% fewer bats were killed at turbines with ultrasonic deterrents fitted. One study found that using an ultrasonic deterrent emitting a constant or pulsed signal had mixed effects on the fatality rates of three bat species. One study found that using ultrasonic deterrents resulted in fewer fatalities for two of three bat species.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Behaviour change (1 study): One paired sites study in the USA found fewer bats flying near one of two wind turbines with an ultrasonic deterrent compared to turbines without, but the effect of the deterrent overall was not significant."

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): Two replicated studies (one randomized, controlled and one paired sites study) in Germany and the USA found that automatically reducing the rotation speed of wind turbine blades when bat activity is predicted to be high resulted in fewer bat fatalities for all bat species combined and for five bat species.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: What conservation actions can be implemented to combat the spread and impact of white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: Identified actions include: (1) culling bats infected with white‑nose syndrome, for which no studies have evaluated effects on bat populations [1012]; (2) vaccinating bats against the white‑nose syndrome pathogen, for which no studies have evaluated effects on bat populations [1011]; and (3) treating bats for infection with a probiotic bacterium, evaluated by two randomized, controlled studies—one in Canada and one in the USA—which reported mixed outcomes: increased survival when little brown bats were treated at the time of infection in a laboratory in Canada, but not when treated 21 days prior [2008]; in a USA mine, increased survival for free‑flying bats but not caged bats [2008]; reduced disease symptoms in laboratory‑caged bats treated at the time of infection in Canada, worse symptoms when treated 21 days prior [2008]; and similar disease severity to untreated bats for caged bats in a USA mine [2008].

tools_called.return_val: NONE - ERRONEOUS TOOL CALL

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to reduce white-nose syndrome infection. One study was in Canada and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: What are the documented outcomes of educating and engaging different groups of people for bat conservation?
relevant_summary: Evidence includes: educating local communities about bats’ ecological roles was followed by fewer hunters intending to hunt bats in a before-and-after study in Ghana [1973]. Educating local communities about disease risks from hunting and eating bat meat was followed by fewer hunters intending to hunt bats in a before-and-after study in Ghana [1974]. Engaging farmers and landowners to manage land for bats in the UK coincided with an increase in the overall population of greater horseshoe bats at four maternity roosts over five years and produced 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha [1936]. No studies were found evaluating the effects of educating farmers, land managers and local communities about the benefits of bats to improve habitat management [2040], or educating farmers, local communities and pest controllers to reduce indiscriminate culling of vampire bats [2044].

query: What is the extent of evidence for actions to mitigate pollution from agricultural sources to benefit bats?
relevant_summary: Evidence for actions that directly mitigate agricultural pollution to benefit bats is limited. Planting riparian buffer strips has no studies evaluating effects on bat populations (2016). Preventing pollution from agricultural land or forestry from entering watercourses has no studies evaluating effects on bat populations (2015). In contrast, using organic farming instead of conventional farming—an approach that reduces synthetic chemical inputs—has been evaluated in 12 studies across Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile: most studies found no difference or higher bat species richness on organic farms compared to non-organic, and mixed results for bat activity with several studies reporting higher overall or species-specific activity on organic farms (961).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Water use (0 studies)
Water availability (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found more soil moisture in plots with buffers, compared to plots without buffers, in some comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found that similar amounts of water were lost as runoff from plots with or without buffers.
Pathogens and pesticides (1 study): One replicated study from the USA found that grass buffer strips decreased the amount of Cryptosporidium parvum (a protozoan pathogen) in runoff, after bovine manure was applied to slopes.
Nutrients (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found less nitrate in runoff from irrigated pastures with buffer strips, but another one found no differences in nitrate or phosphorus in runoff from pastures with or without buffer strips.
Sediments (2 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomized) from the USA found less sediment in runoff from irrigated fields or pastures with buffers, compared to those without buffers, in some or all comparisons.
Implementation options (3 studies): One replicated study from the USA found less C. parvum (a protozoan pathogen) in runoff from flatter buffer strips, compared to steeper. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found more soil moisture in plots with narrower buffer strips, in one of two comparisons. One replicated, randomized, controlled study from the USA found that buffers trapped more runoff in the four weeks after fertilizer application, compared to the next 10 weeks."

query: What design and placement factors influence the successful use of bat boxes by bats?
relevant_summary: Across multiple replicated studies and reviews, bat box use and occupancy were influenced by both design and placement factors: bats used black boxes more than grey, white, or wooden boxes; occupancy was sometimes higher in larger boxes; concrete boxes had higher occupancy than wooden boxes; resin boxes became occupied more quickly than wood in one study; Indiana bats preferred rocket boxes over wooden boxes or bark‑mimic roosts; boxes with two or multiple compartments/chambers had higher or differentiated use (including breeding colonies using standard and 4–5 chamber boxes, with individuals using flat boxes); different species selected different designs; and trunk‑simulating boxes were used by 100% of bats in one study (1024). Placement factors included orientation and/or sunlight exposure affecting occupancy in several studies (with one study finding no effect); mixed results for height (some studies finding effects and others none); higher occupancy on buildings than on trees in two studies; higher occupancy in certain habitat contexts (e.g., farm forestry vs native forest; pine stands vs mixed deciduous; forest fragments vs pasture); higher occupancy when boxes were installed where bats were known to roost previously; and greater likelihood of occupancy when a larger number of boxes were installed across a site (1024).

  "action_title": "Provide bat boxes for roosting bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Forty-four studies evaluated the effects of providing bat boxes for roosting bats on bat populations. Twenty-seven studies were in Europe, nine studies were in North America, four studies were in Australia, two studies were in South America, and one study was a worldwide review.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (44 STUDIES)

Uptake (9 studies): Nine replicated studies in Europe and the USA found that the number of bats using bat boxes increased by 2–10 times up to 10 years after installation.
Use (43 studies): Forty-one of 43 studies (including 34 replicated studies and two reviews) in Europe, the USA, South America, and Australia found that bats used bat boxes installed in forest or woodland, forestry plantations, farmland, pasture, wetlands, urban areas and buildings, bridges, underpasses or unknown habitats. The other two studies in the USA and UK found that bats displaced from buildings did not use any of 43 bat houses of four different designs or 12 heated bat boxes of one design. One review of 109 studies across Europe, North America and Asia found that 72 bat species used bat boxes, although only 18 species commonly used them, and 31 species used them as maternity roosts. Twenty-two studies (including 17 replicated studies, one before-and-after study and two reviews) found bats occupying less than half of bat boxes provided (0–49%). Nine replicated studies found bats occupying more than half of bat boxes provided (54–100%).

OTHER (23 STUDIES)

Bat box design (16 studies): Three studies in Germany, Portugal and Australia found that bats used black bat boxes more than grey, white or wooden boxes. One of two studies in Spain and the USA found higher occupancy rates in larger bat boxes. One study in the USA found that bats used both resin and wood cylindrical bat boxes, but another study in the USA found that resin bat boxes became occupied more quickly than wood boxes. One study in the UK found higher occupancy rates in concrete than wooden bat boxes. One study in the USA found that Indiana bats used rocket boxes more than wooden bat boxes or bark-mimic roosts. One study in Spain found that more bats occupied bat boxes that had two compartments than one compartment in the breeding season. One study in Lithuania found that bat breeding colonies occupied standard and four/five chamber bat boxes and individuals occupied flat bat boxes. Four studies in the USA, UK, Spain and Australia found bats selecting four of nine, three of five, three of four and one of five bat box designs. One study in the UK found that different bat box designs were used by different species. One study in Costa Rica found that bat boxes simulating tree trunks were used by 100% of bats and in group sizes similar to natural roosts.
Bat box position (11 studies): Three studies in Germany, Spain and the USA found that bat box orientation and/or the amount of exposure to sunlight affected bat occupancy, and one study in Spain found that orientation did not have a significant effect on occupancy. Two studies in the UK and Italy found that bat box height affected occupancy, and two studies in Spain and the USA found no effect of height. Two studies in the USA and Spain found higher occupancy of bat boxes on buildings than on trees. One study in Australia found that bat boxes were occupied more often in farm forestry sites than in native forest, one study in Poland found higher occupancy in pine relative to mixed deciduous stands, and one study in Costa Rica found higher occupancy in forest fragments than in pasture. One study in the USA found higher occupancy rates in areas where bats were known to roost prior to installing bat boxes. One review in the UK found that bat boxes were more likely to be occupied when a greater number of bat boxes were installed across a site."

query: How do different types of purpose-built road crossing structures compare in effectiveness for bats?
relevant_summary: Bat gantries/bridges: Three studies reported use patterns; two UK studies found fewer bats used gantries than crossed the road below at traffic height, and one gantry was not used at all; one French study found a temporary gantry was used by three bat species/species groups, but almost half of crossing bats flew over the road at other locations [978]. Overpasses: Four studies reported mixed use; two replicated studies in Ireland and France found two or three bat species/species groups used overpasses but up to three-quarters of bats crossed below at traffic height or at other nearby locations; one UK study found an overpass with planters was used by two-thirds of crossing bats while an unvegetated, paved overpass was not used; an Australian site comparison recorded the same number of bat species at an overpass as in nearby forest and bushland [977]. Underpasses/culverts: Eight studies reported bats used underpasses and culverts and also crossed above roads in varying proportions; in Australia, clutter-adapted species used small culverts/underpasses more than open- or edge-adapted species; in France, use by five bat species was influenced by underpass type and height, road width, and surrounding forest and hedgerows [976]. Hop-overs: No studies were found evaluating effectiveness as bat crossing structures [980].

query: For arid regions, what is the evidence on the effectiveness of creating or managing water sources to support bat populations?
relevant_summary: Evidence specific to arid-area water management is limited: no studies were found that evaluated managing natural water bodies in arid areas to prevent desiccation for bats (2027). Creating artificial water sources has been studied in five countries (USA, Germany, South Africa, Israel, Mexico): replicated studies reported bat activity (relative abundance) was similar or higher over reservoirs, wastewater treatment pools, heliponds, drainage ditches, retention ponds, and farm/cattle ponds than over natural wetlands, nearby vineyards, surrounding forest, or grassland/crops; species richness over farm ponds was similar to other nearby habitats (959). Managing livestock water troughs affected bat use and drinking success: removing livestock modifications increased drinking frequency and reduced the number of approaches before successful drinking; larger, full tanks with sparse surrounding vegetation had more bats drinking than smaller, half-full tanks with no or dense vegetation (1951). Creating or maintaining small dams: a replicated site comparison in Portugal found reservoirs created by small dams had greater activity of four bat species than the streams feeding them (1997). Wetland restoration: a replicated, controlled, before–after study in the USA found restoring wetlands increased overall bat activity, and restored wetlands had similar activity to undisturbed wetlands (2036). Managing ditches to benefit bats: no studies found (1944).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twelve studies evaluated the effects of using organic farming instead of conventional farming on bat populations. Eight studies were in Europe, two in the USA, one in Canada and one in Chile.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, paired sites study in the USA found that the composition of bat species did not differ between organic and non-organic farms.
Richness/diversity (7 studies): Five of seven replicated, paired sites or site comparison studies in Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile found that the number of bat species did not differ between organic and non-organic farms. The other two studies found more bat species on organic farms than non-organic farms.

POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Abundance (12 studies): Five of nine replicated, paired sites or site comparison studies in Europe, the USA, Canada and Chile found that overall bat activity (relative abundance) and common pipistrelle activity did not differ between organic and non-organic farms. The other four studies found higher overall bat activity, bat feeding activity, Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and activity of four of seven bat species on organic farms than non-organic farms. Two replicated, paired sites and site comparison studies in the UK found higher activity of Myotis species over water and rivers on organic farms than non-organic farms, but no differences were found for other species or habitats. One replicated, site comparison study in France found higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields than two of three types of conventionally managed fields.

query: What are the outcomes and success rates associated with ex-situ bat conservation actions like captive breeding and rehabilitation?
relevant_summary: Evidence on ex‑situ bat conservation is limited for captive breeding and more developed for rehabilitation. No studies were found that evaluated breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white‑nose syndrome [2009], and no studies were found that evaluated the effects of releasing captive‑bred bats on bat populations [2039]. Four studies evaluated rehabilitating injured/orphaned bats: 70–90% of hand‑reared pipistrelle bats survived for at least 4–14 days after release, with six of 21 joining wild colonies [2054]; pipistrelles that flew in a large flight cage for longer periods before release survived longer and were more active than those with shorter or small‑enclosure flight [2054]; 13% of ringed hand‑reared pipistrelles were found alive in bat boxes 38 days to almost four years after release [2054]; two orphaned greater spear‑nosed bats survived over three months in captivity and increased in body weight and size to normal within 60 days [2054].

  "action_id": "2054",
  "action_title": "Rehabilitate injured/orphaned bats to maintain wild bat populations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of rehabilitating injured/orphaned bats on bat populations. Two studies were in the UK, one was in Italy and one in Brazil.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Survival (4 studies): One study in Brazil found that two hand-reared orphaned greater spear-nosed bats survived for over three months in captivity. Two studies in the UK and Italy found that 70–90% of hand-reared pipistrelle bats survived for at least 4–14 days after release into the wild, and six of 21 bats joined wild bat colonies. One study in the UK found that pipistrelle bats that flew in a large flight cage for long periods before release survived for longer and were more active than bats that flew for short periods or in a small enclosure. One study in the UK found that 13% of ringed hand-reared pipstrelle bats were found alive in bat boxes 38 days to almost four years after release into the wild.
Condition (1 study): One study in Brazil found that two orphaned greater spear-nosed bats increased in body weight and size after being hand-reared, and reached a normal size for the species after 60 days.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}
